segments.text: Yeah, I guess I'm saying a big family in contrast to what exists now.
We're such a big organization now that we kind of feel, I think, separate in our own
more strongly with others in our own fields outside of our own institutions than we do even sometimes in our own institutions.
I feel that here.
And I was out of Scripps a couple of years ago on sabbatical, and I felt it there, too.
Quite different from what it used to be.
Probably associated with the bigness of the field.
200 research staff here and 200 or 300 at Scripps.
Right.
So it's a big field, at least among the big institutions.
Not big compared to other fields, but I feel the bigness of it now compared to what it used to be.
And we're kind of split off into our separate disciplines to a large extent.
So we've lost a little bit of that kind of perhaps adventuresome togetherness kind of spirit that we used to have.

we're doing more specialized things more detailed things that are still exciting i feel so where should i go from here well uh so i only have one question about revel about this time revel is coming under a great deal of criticism concerning administration of scripps institution of oceanography uh and and i take it that was not your impression at all working with him or i didn't have that feeling he uh i think rogers
way of organizing scripts, which essentially set the pattern for scripts to the present day, was to bring in really good people and let them really work on their own thing.
And that perhaps created some animosities among these really good people.
They were competing to some extent for funds and position in the university, and perhaps power to some extent.
I didn't get involved with that too much in my own research.
At least, I didn't feel it too much.
Perhaps because I was working under Russ Raitt, who didn't have very many of those aspirations, I don't think.
I didn't feel those pressures very much.
But I knew these undercurrents were running its roots.
I could see them around me.
Well, I have the impression, may I be accurate, that as a matter of fact, if I may use the term, all the great men who ran the good institutions about this time,

went through that, that is both Lamont and here at Woods Hole, that they tended to bring money down sort of in a block, sort of just give it to you and ask you what you could do and then come back a couple years later and check and if you did it okay and if you didn't you were gone.
Did you prefer it to operate that way?
Yeah, that was nice for me as a graduate student, because it means I didn't have to scramble for my own funding.
Like now, I'd probably have to write a research proposal to get funding.
And I didn't have any need to do that at the time.
Some money just sort of came to me through professors who wanted this job done.
And I said, here, you have this amount of money.
Why don't you go out and see what you can do with this instrumentation?
And essentially we went to see, you know, funded.
And there it was.
You're right.
The money was a lot easier then.
But we had to produce.
Partly because in addition to the rivalry among research interests and scripts, there was also an intense rivalry between institutions.
Like Scripps wanted to do a better job than Lamont in seismic refraction, or heat flow, or whatever it might be, or Woods Hole.
And there was always that competition, I think, for the federal dollar going on at the institutions.
I think that helped bring Oceania to being all great fast.
Because these great men, Ravel, Ewing,
and Islam, maybe, here, and Woods Hope, who was more a physical oceanographer, helped really get the thing going.
They were the leaders.
They were definitely leaders, something we don't see so much of anymore, either nationally or even in our institutions, I think, to some extent.
We have directors, but not necessarily leaders.
Right.
Well, it might be, you know, that
It's more difficult as the scholarly world has become more specialized to find someone with a broad-based background to lead an institution.
I'm struck by your comments, for example, which appeared again and again in interviews, that each of you have become, in effect, more specialized, less of a general oceanographer.
Would you agree with that?
I think that's to some extent true.
We haven't, hardly any of us, been able to keep up with all the new developments in oceanography.
So in a relative sense, we've all become specialists to some extent.
We may have been more generalists in the past just because there wasn't as much to know about.
I think that's true.
But I kind of started out as a specialist.
I wasn't really a generalist like Ravel.
I think he always tried to impress on us the need for being a general oceanographer.
And all the courses that we took at Scripps were directed toward that way.
We took courses in biology, physical oceanography, chemistry, geology, and geophysics.
That was required of all students to take those at Scripps, as it is here, too.
So we try to get every student at least get
You didn't get involved with all the fields of research.
You were in your own field, even at that time, 1956, when I started.
I was a specialist in geology, geophysics of the oceans.
And that perhaps limits one's abilities to comprehend all of oceanography.
I think that's true.
I feel that.
So then you decided to leave Scripps and go to UNESCO.
Yes.
A career change.
Sort of a career change, although I was always intending to do it as a temporary thing to see how I liked the administration of the ocean.
This was an administrative job.
I wasn't doing any more of my own research.
I didn't pretend that I was going to do that for the next couple of years.
I had a two-year appointment to get us going.
And I thought that would help broaden me, and I think it did, to expose me to a lot of people working in oceanography, although it didn't expose me as much as I'd hoped to the working oceanographer.
It exposed me to more of the administrator and the politician in oceanography.

responsible for meetings of the IOC, the International Oceanographic Commission, in addition to carrying out a program of assisting countries in oceanographic research, maybe developing countries who are just getting their oceanographic programs started.
I was one of four persons in that office.
I had a Russian boss, Konstantin Fedorov, and a German and a Japanese colleague who worked with me in the office for those two years.
Gahil Temple, who's now at Keel, and
Takenuchi, who's somewhere in Japan now.
I don't know where he is.
Meteorological agency or something like that.
He was a physical oceanographer.
And I was a geologist, geophysicist, and Hempo was a biologist.
And better off, our director was also a physical oceanographer.
So I was the only geologist.
But I got involved in all fields of oceanography in that department meeting, administratively.
So the frustrating thing about UNESCO was that the time constant of doing things was so long that by the time I'd been there for two years, half the projects I started hadn't been finished.
And I felt kind of frustrated in that.
I enjoyed the time there and interacting with a lot of people, but I felt strongly the need to get back into my own research activity, too.
So I decided in 1966 that I really had had enough of ministering oceanography on an international basis and I wanted to get back into my own research fields here in Woods Hole, which I did.
And I got back here again into heat cell research and had had a
fairly major program here for the past 10 or 12 years, 10 or 11 years.
How long have I been here?
Sixty-six.
Yeah, 11 years.
And have been continuing that work here.
And I, you know, it's been a very pleasant experience.
When I look back on the time, it looks like, you know, what's happened to the past 20 years.
I don't know.
It's like, well, I think that's true of any field that you enjoy.
And I've gotten myself involved with some other geophysical fields at the same time.
Some electromagnetic induction research, which is a new kind of field coming along.
We're getting that started here at Woods Hole.
I've been involved with it for three or four years now.
And that's directed to...
looking at electrical conductivity in the oceans, beneath the oceans, as a function of depth, trying to understand what the temperature and chemical structure might be beneath the oceans.
But you could see Woods Hole is similarly organized to Scripps, but not quite the same.
The main differences are here, I think, that we tended
partly from the characters of the people here, to be more tightly directed.
That is, the geophysics department, partly for historical reasons, tended to do things as a group.
We went out on cruises as a group.
And I was in on some of these when I first came here, not so much lately.
But you went to sea as a geophysics group rather than, as I mentioned in my first group of scripts, as physical oceanographers, geologists, biologists, et cetera.
Tend to be more of a discipline oriented research group here.
And we were just starting to get organized by departments here at Woods Hole.
compared to Scripps, which had a long, long organization structure.
I think Woods Hole is just somewhat behind in getting organized compared to Scripps.
Woods Hole didn't exist before 1930, and Scripps existed way back until the early 1900s as a marine biological station.
Almost all of the oceanographic institutions started off in biology.
That's right.
Which is interesting.
Very few started out as geological institutions, with a few exceptions.
I don't know how the others did.
Anyway, I think now we're seeing a time of intense competition for research dollars right now.
I'm feeling it.
Everybody's feeling it.
It's not quite so enjoyable as it used to be when you have to really beg for your dollars.
But I think everybody here feels the enjoyment of working at sea.
One thing I find here, I was at Scripps a couple of years ago on sabbatical.
I just went back for a year to participate in some of these electromagnetic induction studies with Jim Cox at Scripps.
with a separate group at Scripps, not very directed compared to one here, which might involve the whole of the physics department.
But I found that one of the differences between here and Scripps was the way in which, how do I describe it?
that Scripps is kind of a bigger place now that involves the whole university.
And people are involved from the university in Scripps, and there's not so much emphasis on the seacoing part of things anymore in Scripps as it used to be.
Here, there's a much more relative emphasis, I think, on the seagoing aspects of things.
Perhaps because we're isolated down here on the Cape.
We're not associated with a major university except with MIT in an educational sense.
But we don't have any close physical ties with MIT.
And our business is oceanography down here.
That's it, period.
That's the way we get funding.
Whereas Scripps is sort of part now of the big UCSD campus and is more of a general campus.
That's both an advantage and a disadvantage, because it means that you can't.
We here at Woods Hole, for example, can't draw on the expertise quickly and easily from other fields, geophysics or physics, for example, or chemistry.
We have to go to MIT or some other place to really get involved with people from those fields.
On the other hand, it means we can be somewhat unfettered.
We're not part of a large research or a large educational institution which has its rules and regulations.
We're a fairly small institution.
And fortunately, we have the ship facilities here that I think are as good as anywhere.
Probably as good as scriptry and better.
And that's been one of the very attractive things to me here at Woods Hole, is the emphasis on seagoing activity and keeping first-class seagoing activity going.
Whereas I think Scripps has left their seagoing activity dropping, compared to what I saw when I was there 20 years ago.
And that's unfortunate to some extent, because Scripps is a wonderful place to do seagoing work.
But there are a lot of other institutions now that have come along in a much stronger way.
Smaller institutions, but still quite viable ones, such as University of Hawaii, Texas A&M, University of Miami, and Duke University operates the Eastward.
So I think the relative importance has changed between the smaller institutions and the larger institutions.
And I think the smaller institutions have a relatively larger influence in hunk of the pie than they used to back in the old days.
after World War II.
It was mainly the major institutions where the World War II research was carried out.
And that carried over into the funding, at least for a few years.
Yes, I think so.
That's the way I felt.
So it's a more pluralistic kind of activity, divided among more institutions and more programs.
I'm not involved with it, but Dave Ross down here runs the
What am I trying to say?
The Sea Grant program, which involves all kinds of applied aspects of research and is a very potent force now in new avenues for oceanographic research that are more applied.
I guess I'm still a basic oceanographic research scientist.
I don't get so much involved with the applied aspects.
And I think Woods Hole is still a basic research institution, although there have been a lot of pressures lately to get involved with applied research, and even from the director on down here.
And that's where the new funding is.
I think we're always tempted to get involved with more applied kind of research programs.
But I don't think anyone claims yet that we know enough about the basic
fundamentals of how the ocean works or how the earth works to say that we can just do applied work now.
At least I don't feel that way, and I don't think very many people do.
I think Woods Hole and Scripps and Lamont still have a basic research orientation, and they're going to contribute a lot to these applied programs that are going on now.
I don't know how much detail you want on what my history has been here at Woods Hole.
or who I've known here.
Well, now, what I'd like for you to do now is, now you're reentering work with heat flow.
I'd like for you to talk some about what you did when you arrived, how you set up your research.
What do you feel as if you discovered in heat flow?
How do you feel like this contributed to the idea of spreading?
What was your reaction when you began to see the implication of the two?
Yeah, this happened, the idea of seafloor spreading and plate tectonics, which is sort of the revolution in our field, really happened about the time I was over in UNESCO.
And I was getting some feedback from that in the indirect sort of way, but I wasn't involved directly with, at the time, with the research that was developing then.
You know, the real evidence came from the magnetic anomalies on the seafloor.
And that came out with Fred Vine and others about 1965, 1966 period, just when I was coming back here to Woods Hole.
And so that was sort of a stimulus for us in the geothermal aspects of things to try to understand
what was happening to the heat flow.
Could the heat flow be explained in the same way?
And we knew in a general sense that it could, because we found these high heat flow values on ridges.
But we didn't understand all the scattering values.
We had a lot of scattering heat flow data, and still do.
And it's only the past few years where we started to understand the cause of that
models of hydrothermal circulation.
There's water circulating down in the crust where the rocks, when they're formed at the ridges, get pretty well cracked up, probably thermally or mechanically.
So water can circulate down in the rocks and bring the heat out.
And we don't measure that with our measurements because we measure only the conductive part of the heat.
And so where we had conductive measurements, we'd get both high and low values scattered very close together.
We could never understand why that should exist on the sea floor.
Because theoretically, if everything were conducted, we should get a uniform decrease of heat flow away from the ridges as the crust cools.
We didn't find that.
So heat flow was not a major contributor to the development of the idea of sea floor spread.
We had problems and still do have problems understanding the distribution of heat flow.
But it has contributed more recently in a major way to the models of the way the plates cool with time.
Because by eliminating, yeah,
of the circulating, what we infer to be a circulating pattern of water in the earth's crust in that area.
And we've mapped very detailed, small-scale variations of heat flow there, which can explain easily all of the scatter that we've been measuring in the past 20 years, especially in the ridge crust.
There's a lot of interesting aspects of that that I don't think I need to go into now here, but that we're trying to develop an understanding of that hydrothermal circulation pattern.
But we're also trying to understand the basic cooling of the plates now as a function of time out to as old as the oceans get.
We haven't done that very well.
There's still a lot of scatter in the data because of the way the data was taken in the early days.

So we're developing a lot of very specific experiments to understand the heat flow as a function of age of the ocean crust so we can get a smooth curve that's connected with the aging of the plates with time.
And that hasn't been easy because in the early days, right after sea floor spreading,
I think heat flow tended to be discounted a lot because it wasn't understood.
We didn't understand this aspect of hydrothermal circulation until about the early 1970s.
So essentially, when I first came back here to Woods Hole, we were making these long transects for several years of heat flow right across the oceans.
And it clearly demonstrated that the heat flow measurements couldn't fit very well to an idea of sea floor spreading, cooling of a plate in a simple mode.
But I think these measurements were instrumental in helping us develop this
idea of hydrothermal circulation in the crust, a mechanism which had been suspected and not really demonstrated in any clear way, except by heat flow measurements.
Recently, I think this work on the Galapagos has demonstrated it fairly clearly that it holds pretty well.
We measured hot water coming out of the crust, for example, with Albin in a very detailed survey right at the ridge crest.
The Galapagos was an interesting place to go to because not only the
historical aspects associated with Darwin's discoveries there.

We also discovered some new biology on the seafloor associated with these fins, which is interesting, because Darwin discovered a new biology on the islands there, and the biological principles that he expounded in terms of evolution and things of this sort.
Now the marine biologists are very interested in these new discoveries on the seafloor in the same area.
It's kind of an interesting connection.
So a return to history.
Return to history, so to speak.
But we don't know very much about that biology yet.
The biologists are really excited now and want to get back to the area in another year or two with the Alvin submersible to look at things.
Alvin is a new technology that's come along, too, very nicely in the past few years.
Essentially, Woods Hole took on the burden about when I came back here, a little before I arrived here, of supporting the research

submersible vessel that could be used by anyone who wanted to use it in the oceanographic community had a tough time for a long time supporting that kind of activity because it simply didn't have the capabilities to get down to the deep sea floor where the interesting geology and geophysics occurred until recently.
It increased its depth capability three, four years ago to 12,000 feet instead of 6,000.
6,000 feet eliminated this from all the oceans, except for the continental shelves.
There were very few people that could do much with the outland on the continental shelves.
Well, there were people here, sedimentologists and geologists, who were using it and did use it.
Ken Emery, Dave Ross, and other people used it on the shelves here.
But, you know, it turns out the new, all the driving
And a lot of the driving force, I think, for big funding in oceanography came from the geological, geophysical side of things in the deep oceans.
It still does to some extent.
I don't think our revolution has stopped yet, really.
Because now we're working on the problems of understanding the driving forces associated with plate tectonics.
What makes it go?
And we know very little about it right now.
And we're now developing some long,
deep penetrating experiments, one of which is this electromagnetic induction studies that I'm starting to get into, to learn about the depth structure of the plates and beneath the plates.
What's the material beneath the plates like?
How does it distribute in space and over the motions?
That's just beginning.
I think that's going to be a new story for the next 10 or 15 years.
Do you think that'll, at least in terms of your interest and specialty, you think that'll be the direction of oceanography?
That'll be one direction of oceanography.
I think we're going to see several directions in oceanography over the next few years.
I think it's perhaps like the proliferation of the field itself.
We're going to see several major directions in oceanography.
What are they?
Well, one is associated with the ocean waters themselves.

The physical oceanographers are sort of having a revolution by themselves right now in terms of understanding the details of the circulating patterns of currents in the oceans and the time scales of the circulations and the flow of energy, sort of the climate in the ocean, so to speak, and the way it interacts with the climate in the atmosphere.
I think there's a lot of evidence now that the oceans' distribution of temperatures and ocean waters controls what happens over the continents.
Yes.

To a large extent, you probably talk to people at Scripps about this, because they're very much involved with that, because it looks like the Pacific Ocean is probably the controlling factor on the weather over the United States.
of these new biological communities in the Galapagos.
What do those mean in terms of evolution of creatures on the seafloor?
These vents that were observed, hot water vents on the Galapagos, are only a few thousand years old.
And here we have new creatures that have probably been developed there in this period of a few thousand years that don't exist elsewhere outside of those areas.
How did they develop?
Where did they come from?
How do they get introduced?
How do they live?
What do they live on down there?
There's a lot of theories going around right now about sulfur reducing bacteria and how they contribute to the food chain at the seafloor from these vent areas.
It may be very localized, but they may have some long ranging aspects or implications for the development of sea life in the ocean.
I don't know.
That's a story that biologists need to tell, and I think probably will be taught.
And then in our field, in geological oceanography, I think the big push is going to be to understand the driving forces behind plate tectonics.
What are the deeper motions that are going on?
How fast are they?
How are they distributed?
Do we have big convection cells under the Earth?
Where are they?
What is their time scale?
What drives these motions in the air?
Is it heat coming from the interior that drives them?
If so, why?
Where are the heat sources in the air?
These will be difficult problems to get at.
We may not be able to answer them unambiguously because we can't get down there and sample things.
100 kilometers down, how are we going to sample it?
But the tools we have are geophysical.
Heat flow, electromagnetic, seismic,
All of these indirect methods are going to be the ways in which we learn about this, and I suspect I'm going to be involved with that probably for the rest of my career here in oceanography.
So, in a sense, my early heat flow work is being generalized into a more broader geophysical description of how the Earth works.
I've been studying it in the oceans, peripherally on the continents, but I think that's...
the relationship we see now.
And we want to tie the oceans and the continents together when we make this kind of a study.
How do the continental masses react to these sea floor spreading forces that are going on?
It may turn out that a lot of the
activity or organization of research in the oceans will be now applied to the continents.
The continents are much more difficult to understand in many ways, even though we're living right on top of them and have access to them.
So it may be that many of these geophysical methods, big geophysical programs, can now be applied to continental areas to understand the deep structure there.
